clusters.title: Cholera is spreading fast, yet it can be stopped. Why haven’t we consigned it to history? | Hakainde Hichilema and Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
clusters.neutral_headline: Cholera is spreading fast, yet it can be stopped. Why haven’t we consigned it to history?

items.title: Cholera is spreading fast, yet it can be stopped. Why haven’t we consigned it to history? | Hakainde Hichilema and Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
items.standfirst: Vaccine production must be expanded to combat this ancient disease, especially in Africa. But a lack of political will is holding us backHakainde Hichilema is president of Zambia. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus is director general of the World Health OrganizationThe last outbreak of cholera in Britain was in 1866; in the United States there has not been an outbreak since 1911.And yet today people are sick with this ancient disease in 32 countries, with more than 6,800 deaths reported so far this year –already exceeding all of last year’s toll of 6,000 deaths, which was itself a 50% increase on 2023.Hakainde Hichilema is president of Zambia and control champion for the Global Task Force on Cholera Control. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus is director general of the World Health Organization Continue reading...
items.content: Vaccine production must be expanded to combat this ancient disease, especially in Africa. But a lack of political will is holding us backHakainde Hichilema is president of Zambia. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus is director general of the World Health OrganizationThe last outbreak of cholera in Britain was in 1866; in the United States there has not been an outbreak since 1911.And yet today people are sick with this ancient disease in 32 countries, with more than 6,800 deaths reported so far this year –already exceeding all of last year’s toll of 6,000 deaths, which was itself a 50% increase on 2023.Hakainde Hichilema is president of Zambia and control champion for the Global Task Force on Cholera Control. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus is director general of the World Health Organization Continue reading...

ai_summary: Cholera cases are increasing, with over 6,800 deaths reported this year.
Vaccine production must expand to combat the disease, especially in Africa.
A lack of political will is hindering efforts to control cholera outbreaks.
The last cholera outbreak in Britain was in 1866, and in the US in 1911.
The article highlights the need for increased global action against cholera.

clusters.title: RFK Jr to urge Americans to eat more saturated fats, alarming health experts
clusters.neutral_headline: RFK Jr to urge Americans to eat more saturated fats, alarming health experts

items.title: RFK Jr to urge Americans to eat more saturated fats, alarming health experts
items.standfirst: Guidance from health and human services secretary contradicts decades of dietary recommendationsRobert F Kennedy Jr, the health and human services (HHS) secretary, is planning to issue guidance encouraging Americans to eat more saturated fats, contradicting decades of dietary recommendations and alarming experts.“My response and sort of counsel to myself was to stay calm, and let’s see what happens, because there was no indication given as to how, why, when this potential shift would occur,” said Cheryl Anderson, an American Heart Association board member and professor at the University of California, San Diego’s school of public health and human longevity science. Continue reading...
items.content: Guidance from health and human services secretary contradicts decades of dietary recommendationsRobert F Kennedy Jr, the health and human services (HHS) secretary, is planning to issue guidance encouraging Americans to eat more saturated fats, contradicting decades of dietary recommendations and alarming experts.“My response and sort of counsel to myself was to stay calm, and let’s see what happens, because there was no indication given as to how, why, when this potential shift would occur,” said Cheryl Anderson, an American Heart Association board member and professor at the University of California, San Diego’s school of public health and human longevity science. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. plans to encourage more saturated fat consumption.
This guidance contradicts decades of dietary recommendations.
Health experts are expressing concern about the proposed advice.
The HHS secretary's guidance is causing alarm among experts.
Experts are waiting to see how and why the shift will occur.

clusters.title: Offer cancer patients exercise on NHS, major charity urges
clusters.neutral_headline: Offer cancer patients exercise on NHS, major charity urges

items.title: Offer cancer patients exercise on NHS, major charity urges
items.standfirst: Maggie’s says embedding activities such as yoga, tai chi and Nordic walking into care could boost chances of survivalCancer patients should be offered yoga, tai chi and Nordic walking as part of their NHS care to boost their chances of survival and stop tumours returning, a major charity has said.Maggie’s, which operates 27 cancer support centres across the UK, is urging NHS bosses to “embed” exercise into the care offered to the 386,000 Britons diagnosed with the disease every year. Continue reading...
items.content: Maggie’s says embedding activities such as yoga, tai chi and Nordic walking into care could boost chances of survivalCancer patients should be offered yoga, tai chi and Nordic walking as part of their NHS care to boost their chances of survival and stop tumours returning, a major charity has said.Maggie’s, which operates 27 cancer support centres across the UK, is urging NHS bosses to “embed” exercise into the care offered to the 386,000 Britons diagnosed with the disease every year. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Maggie's urges the NHS to offer exercise to cancer patients.
Activities like yoga, tai chi, and Nordic walking are suggested.
Embedding exercise could boost survival chances and prevent recurrence.
The charity operates 27 cancer support centers across the UK.
The proposal aims to improve care for 386,000 diagnosed annually.

clusters.title: Americans brace for food stamps to run out: ‘The greatest hunger catastrophe since the Great Depression’
clusters.neutral_headline: Americans brace for food stamps to run out: ‘The greatest hunger catastrophe since the Great Depression’

items.title: Americans brace for food stamps to run out: ‘The greatest hunger catastrophe since the Great Depression’
items.standfirst: Nearly 42 million people in danger as federal government shutdown continues and Snap funding to end 1 NovemberTwo decades ago, Sara Carlson, then a mother of three, was newly single because of a traumatic event, and the US’s food stamp program, now called the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap), helped her feed her children with free food supplies.“I wouldn’t have been able to afford to live,” said Carlson, 45, who lives in Rochester, Minnesota, and now works as an operations manager for a wealth-management firm and serves on the board of Channel One Regional Food Bank, which works to increase food access. Continue reading...
items.content: Nearly 42 million people in danger as federal government shutdown continues and Snap funding to end 1 NovemberTwo decades ago, Sara Carlson, then a mother of three, was newly single because of a traumatic event, and the US’s food stamp program, now called the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap), helped her feed her children with free food supplies.“I wouldn’t have been able to afford to live,” said Carlson, 45, who lives in Rochester, Minnesota, and now works as an operations manager for a wealth-management firm and serves on the board of Channel One Regional Food Bank, which works to increase food access. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nearly 42 million people face potential food insecurity.
The federal government shutdown threatens SNAP funding.
SNAP funding is scheduled to end on November 1.
The article highlights the impact of the shutdown on food assistance.
A mother of three was helped by the food stamp program.

clusters.title: Surgeons remove up to 100 magnets from New Zealand teenager’s intestines
clusters.neutral_headline: Surgeons remove up to 100 magnets from New Zealand teenager’s intestines

items.title: Surgeons remove up to 100 magnets from New Zealand teenager’s intestines
items.standfirst: Boy, 13, swallowed the high-power magnets after apparently buying them from the online retailer TemuA 13-year-old boy in New Zealand swallowed up to 100 high-power magnets he bought online, forcing surgeons to remove tissue from his intestines, doctors said on Friday.After suffering four days of abdominal pain, the unnamed teenager was taken to Tauranga hospital in the North Island. “He disclosed ingesting approximately 80 to 100 5x2mm high-power (neodymium) magnets about one week prior,” said a report by hospital doctors in the New Zealand Medical Journal.This article’s byline was amended on 25 October 2025 to correct the news agency it was attributed to. An earlier version incorrectly attributed it to Associated Foreign Press; however the correct agency was Agence France-Presse. Continue reading...
items.content: Boy, 13, swallowed the high-power magnets after apparently buying them from the online retailer TemuA 13-year-old boy in New Zealand swallowed up to 100 high-power magnets he bought online, forcing surgeons to remove tissue from his intestines, doctors said on Friday.After suffering four days of abdominal pain, the unnamed teenager was taken to Tauranga hospital in the North Island. “He disclosed ingesting approximately 80 to 100 5x2mm high-power (neodymium) magnets about one week prior,” said a report by hospital doctors in the New Zealand Medical Journal.This article’s byline was amended on 25 October 2025 to correct the news agency it was attributed to. An earlier version incorrectly attributed it to Associated Foreign Press; however the correct agency was Agence France-Presse. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A 13-year-old boy swallowed up to 100 magnets.
The boy bought the magnets online from Temu.
Surgeons removed tissue from the boy's intestines.
The boy experienced four days of abdominal pain.
The magnets were 5x2mm high-power neodymium magnets.

clusters.title: Scientists demand cancer warnings on bacon and ham sold in UK
clusters.neutral_headline: Scientists demand cancer warnings on bacon and ham sold in UK

items.title: Scientists demand cancer warnings on bacon and ham sold in UK
items.standfirst: Successive governments criticised for doing ‘virtually nothing’ to reduce risk in decade since cancer link foundBacon and ham sold in the UK should carry cigarette-style labels warning that chemicals in them cause bowel cancer, scientists say.Their demand comes as they criticise successive British governments for doing “virtually nothing” to reduce the risk from nitrites in the decade since they were found to definitely cause cancer. Continue reading...
items.content: Successive governments criticised for doing ‘virtually nothing’ to reduce risk in decade since cancer link foundBacon and ham sold in the UK should carry cigarette-style labels warning that chemicals in them cause bowel cancer, scientists say.Their demand comes as they criticise successive British governments for doing “virtually nothing” to reduce the risk from nitrites in the decade since they were found to definitely cause cancer. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Scientists want cancer warnings on bacon and ham in the UK.
They criticize governments for inaction on cancer risks.
The warnings would be similar to those on cigarette packs.
The demand is due to the presence of cancer-causing chemicals.
The scientists are concerned about nitrites in processed meats.

clusters.title: ‘I was contaminated’: study reveals how hard it is to avoid pesticide exposure
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘I was contaminated’: study reveals how hard it is to avoid pesticide exposure

items.title: ‘I was contaminated’: study reveals how hard it is to avoid pesticide exposure
items.standfirst: Silicone wristbands worn by volunteers in the Netherlands captured 173 substances in one weekFor decades, Khoji Wesselius has noticed the oily scent of pesticides during spraying periods when the wind has blown through his tiny farming village in a rural corner of the Netherlands.Now, after volunteering in an experiment to count how many such substances people are subjected to, Wesselius and his wife are one step closer to understanding the consequences of living among chemical-sprayed fields of seed potato, sugar beet, wheat, rye and onion. Continue reading...
items.content: Silicone wristbands worn by volunteers in the Netherlands captured 173 substances in one weekFor decades, Khoji Wesselius has noticed the oily scent of pesticides during spraying periods when the wind has blown through his tiny farming village in a rural corner of the Netherlands.Now, after volunteering in an experiment to count how many such substances people are subjected to, Wesselius and his wife are one step closer to understanding the consequences of living among chemical-sprayed fields of seed potato, sugar beet, wheat, rye and onion. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Volunteers wore wristbands to measure pesticide exposure.
The wristbands captured 173 substances in one week.
The study was conducted in the Netherlands.
The study aims to understand the consequences of exposure.
A farmer noticed the scent of pesticides during spraying.

clusters.title: Drax faces lawsuits over claims workers developed asthma from wood dust
clusters.neutral_headline: Drax faces lawsuits over claims workers developed asthma from wood dust

items.title: Drax faces lawsuits over claims workers developed asthma from wood dust
items.standfirst: Current and former employees say they were not adequately protected despite knowledge of health risksTen lawsuits have been filed against Drax after diagnoses of asthma allegedly linked to its wood pellet fuel, it has been revealed.Current and former workers at the UK’s largest power station claim they have not been adequately protected against sustained exposure to wood dust, which can cause serious health problems including asthma, dermatitis and nasal cancer. Continue reading...
items.content: Current and former employees say they were not adequately protected despite knowledge of health risksTen lawsuits have been filed against Drax after diagnoses of asthma allegedly linked to its wood pellet fuel, it has been revealed.Current and former workers at the UK’s largest power station claim they have not been adequately protected against sustained exposure to wood dust, which can cause serious health problems including asthma, dermatitis and nasal cancer. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Drax faces ten lawsuits related to wood dust exposure.
Current and former employees claim inadequate protection.
Wood dust exposure can cause asthma and other health issues.
The lawsuits allege health problems linked to wood pellet fuel.
The workers claim they were not adequately protected.

items.title: Home fined after two disabled residents drowned
items.standfirst: A boat designed for wheelchair users took on water and flipped, trapping the victims.
items.content: A boat designed for wheelchair users took on water and flipped, trapping the victims.

ai_summary: A care home has been fined after two disabled residents drowned in a boating accident.
The boat, designed for wheelchair users, took on water and subsequently flipped over.
The victims were trapped when the boat capsized, leading to their tragic deaths.
The incident occurred at a care home, highlighting safety concerns for residents.
The fine reflects the severity of the incident and the home's responsibility.
